awd_titl_txt: Convergent Learning from Divergent Perspectives:  Interdisciplinary Collaborations in Informal Science Communication
awd_abstract_narration:
As part of its overall strategy to enhance learning in informal environments, the Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program seeks to advance new approaches to, and evidence-based understanding of, the design and development of STEM learning in informal environments. This includes providing multiple pathways for broadening access to and engagement in STEM learning experiences, advancing innovative research on and assessment of STEM learning in informal environments, and developing understandings of deeper learning by participants. This Innovations in Development project will develop a collaborative program to connect and prepare researchers from divergent disciplines to communicate science to publics of all ages in three distinct informal environments:  pop-ups at community events, experiential learning with problem solving events for youth, and presentations at a science museum.   It will study the effects of this program on the identity and motivations of STEM researchers and evaluate the short and medium-term outcomes for public audiences.  Project partners include, The STEAM Factory, OHI/O Informal Learning in Tech Program, and the Center of Science and Industry (COSI) all located in Columbus, Ohio.

The primary goals of this project are as follows.  1) Develop a collaborative program that connects and prepares researchers from divergent disciplines to creatively and effectively communicate science to people of all ages.  2) Evaluate the short and medium-term learning outcomes across different informal learning settings.  3) Study the effect of this collaborative program on the motivations and identify of the researchers.  The specific research question is: In what ways do researchers motivations and identities further develop because of these collaborative experiences with divergent perspectives? A mixed method approach will be used.  Data will be collected and analyzed from 3 cohorts of researchers who implement programs in different informal learning settings.  A series of pre- and post interviews with scientists will be designed to answer the research question above.  Interviews will be grounded in self-determination theory. Later reflective surveys will serve as triangulation for the data.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Convergent Learning from Divergent Perspectives: Interdisciplinary Collaborations in Informal Science Communication was an informal learning-focused project that brought together researchers with diverse disciplinary expertise in science, technology, engineering, arts, and mathematics (STEAM) to collaboratively develop various presentations of content around convergent themes. The project integrated science communication training with collaborative interdisciplinary public engagement in community contexts. We utilized existing informal learning initiatives within Ohio State University (OSU) and the local Columbus, Ohio community, including the OSU STEAM Factory, OHI/O hackathon program, Columbus Science Pub, and the Center for Science and Industry (COSI). The project advanced creative engagement with public audiences of all ages in unstructured and semi-structured learning environments.

We created an informal learning program that brought together researchers from divergent perspectives and disciplines to develop innovative and creative STEM learning experiences through collaborative communication. The program consisted of six components: (1) theme and participant selection through an OSU faculty survey; (2) convergent science communication coaching by COSI; (3) individual and group presentations by cohorts at community events; (3) cohorts’ development of a convergent challenge for a high school hackathon; (5) evaluation of the program’s impact on audience interest and learning; and (6) research on the impact of program participation on faculty’s identity as researchers, teachers, and collaborators. During the program, 16 faculty were trained in interdisciplinary science communication, grouped into one of four interdisciplinary cohorts, and were challenged to develop convergent presentations around a given theme: energy, space, movement, or elements. These faculty cohorts engaged in a total of 36 public events, reaching over 3,000 adults across the U.S. through virtual programs and Qualtrics panels, and over 500 Ohio residents through in-person programs. During the COVID-19 pandemic, we successfully transitioned our program from conducting activities in-person to virtual, synchronous activities, including our training, events and presentations, collaborations, evaluations, and audience engagement. Our project resulted in over 20 products, including publications, posts and conference presentations, virtual storytelling projects, blogs, and a website.

After instituting our informal learning program, we found four key project outcomes: (1) convergent presentations increased audience interest in and curiosity about STEM disciplines, (2) building a network of interdisciplinary scholars increased the number of connections scholars made with interdisciplinary communities and facilitated convergence research, (3) recommendations for creating and evaluating interdisciplinary hackathon challenges were developed, and (4) faculty’s identities as researchers, teachers, and collaborators strengthened as a result of interdisciplinary convergence. Results suggest a beneficial role for collaborative communication strategies to foster interest in STEM, even among people without a background in STEM, and to advance convergent research.

1.     Data from a broader audience of panel respondents shows promise for drawing conclusions about effects of convergent communication on learning, interest, curiosity, and connections across diverse disciplines. We found that collaborative presentations increased self-reported audience interest in engineering compared to the non-collaborative, individual presentations by the same researchers. Additionally, convergent presentations that included the arts had a significant positive impact not only on audience interests in arts but also an increased interest in STEM and the likelihood of sharing what they learned with others.

2.     To understand the culture of grassroots interdisciplinary research, we surveyed members of the STEAM factory in 2017 and 2019, and built a network based on self-reported collaborations among members. Communities within the network are highly interdisciplinary in both years, finding that while the number of active researchers remained roughly constant, the number of connections increased with over 40 new connections. There are more communities in 2019 and the connections between communities is stronger in 2019. Our work shows that informal and self-organized networks can be effective in facilitating convergence research.

3.     We examined the challenges and successes of the interdisciplinary collaborative process of developing hackathon challenges. The collaborations were facilitated by members of the research team for each cohort to create a hackathon design challenge centered around their convergent theme. We compared and aligned features of the challenges and used problem-based learning literature to develop recommendations and criteria for developing and evaluating challenges. Our research provides insight and recommendations for creating and evaluating time-based problem-solving challenges, like hackathons, to facilitate convergent research and learning.

4.     We examined the identity trajectories of each cohort throughout the process to understand how this program impacted their identity development as research professionals. The participants’ identities as researchers and teachers were leveraged throughout the program, and their identities as presenters and collaborators grew. There was a noticeable change in their definition of interdisciplinary collaboration, which broadened from collaborating with those in adjacent fields to collaborating with those across STEAM fields. The research helped identify key elements that cultivate bidirectional learning between scholars across diverse disciplines to develop convergent research ideas.
